==Similar projects==
==Similar projects==
â
+
*[[autopackage]]
â
[[ROX Desktop|ROX]] uses directories ([[Application directory|AppDirs]]) as application bundles.
+
*[http://www.gnome.org/~alexl/glick/ Glick] is a project similar to klik, created by [[Red Hat]] employee [[Alexander Larsson]]<ref>[http://blogs.gnome.org/alexl/2007/08/07/experiments-with-runtime-less-app-bundles/ ''Experiments with runtime-less app-bundles''], by Alexander Larsson, [[August 7]], [[2007]]</ref><ref>[http://arstechnica.com/journals/linux.ars/2007/08/23/glick-brings-better-standalone-application-bundles-to-linux ''Glick brings better standalone application bundles to Linux''], by [[Ryan Paul]], [[Ars Technica]], [[August 23]], [[2007]]</ref><ref>[http://www.kdedevelopers.org/node/2924 klik2 discussions inspire Alexander Larsson (Red Hat/Gnome) to publish 'glick'], by pipitas, [[KDE]] Developers blog, [[August 7]], [[2007]]</ref>. It is intended to be a "runtime-less" [[Bundle (NEXTSTEP)|application bundle]] environment, in which application bundles are executed and ran natively without the need for a running klik/glick client. However, glick currently only addresses a fraction of klik's scope (steps 5 and 6 of the exhibit).
â
+
*[[Zero Install]], another similar project, does address steps 1-5, but does not follow the "one file per application" philosophy.<br />
â
[http://www.gnome.org/~alexl/glick/ Glick] is a project similar to klik, created by [[Red Hat]] employee [[Alexander Larsson]]<ref>[http://blogs.gnome.org/alexl/2007/08/07/experiments-with-runtime-less-app-bundles/ ''Experiments with runtime-less app-bundles''], by Alexander Larsson, [[August 7]], [[2007]]</ref><ref>[http://arstechnica.com/journals/linux.ars/2007/08/23/glick-brings-better-standalone-application-bundles-to-linux ''Glick brings better standalone application bundles to Linux''], by [[Ryan Paul]], [[Ars Technica]], [[August 23]], [[2007]]</ref><ref>[http://www.kdedevelopers.org/node/2924 klik2 discussions inspire Alexander Larsson (Red Hat/Gnome) to publish 'glick'], by pipitas, [[KDE]] Developers blog, [[August 7]], [[2007]]</ref>. It is intended to be a "runtime-less" [[Bundle (NEXTSTEP)|application bundle]] environment, in which application bundles are executed and ran natively without the need for a running klik/glick client. However, glick currently only addresses a fraction of klik's scope (steps 5 and 6 of the exhibit).
+
*[[SFS Technology]] for Linux Tiger and [[Ubuntu]]
â
+
*[[ROX Desktop|ROX]] uses directories ([[Application directory|AppDirs]]) as application bundles.
â
[[Zero Install]], another similar project, does address steps 1-5, but does not follow the "one file per application" philosophy.<br />
  â
